data.title: Elkins, Francis (“Frank”) Dawson (1874-1956)
data.meta_description: Francis (“Frank”) Dawson Elkins was a realtor and insurance broker. He lived at 1900 Comox Street at the time of the 1911 Canada census.   Family Background Francis Dawson Elkins was born on November 27, 1874, in Reading, Berkshire, England. (Some sources say that he was born in 1876 or 1877.) His parents…
data.text:
Francis (“Frank”) Dawson Elkins was a realtor and insurance broker.

He lived at 1900 Comox Street at the time of the 1911 Canada census.

Family Background

Francis Dawson Elkins was born on November 27, 1874, in Reading, Berkshire, England. (Some sources say that he was born in 1876 or 1877.) His parents were Frederick Elkins (1843-1887) and Agnes Mitchell (1842-1935).

Frederick Elkins was baptized in Guildford, Surrey on May 10, 1843.

Frederick trained to become a solicitor.

He married Agnes Mitchell in London, England, on January 25, 1870.

Frederick died in Reading, Berkshire on March 31, 1887.

Agnes Elkins died in Santa Monica, California on November 8, 1935.

To Canada

Frank arrived in Canada about 1890. It appears that he was in Broadview, Manitoba in 1891, and that he was working as a carpenter.

By 1901, Frank was living in Winnipeg, Manitoba, along with his widowed mother, Agnes, who had arrived in Canada in 1898.

To Vancouver

By 1906, Frank was in Vancouver. He was the British Columbia superintendent for the London Guarantee and Accident Company.

Frank and his brother James Edgar Elkins later established a real estate and insurance business called Elkins Brothers. Their offices were in the Union Building at 536 West Hastings Street.

Elkins Brothers – Henderson’s City of Vancouver and North Vancouver Directory – 1909 – page 34.

Marriage to Edna Cook

On April 21, 1908, in Vancouver, Frank married Edna Jacqueline Cook. She was born in the Rural District of Minnedosa, Manitoba, on March 14, 1883. Her parents were Edward Cook (1854-1940) and Maria Douglas (1856-1940).

Life in Vancouver

Frank and Edna lived in Vancouver after their marriage.

In 1911, they moved to 1900 Comox Street for the summer.

Later in 1911, they moved to Shaughnessy Heights.

Military Service

During the First World War, Frank joined the Canadian Expeditionary Forces.

He served in Canada, England and France. He became a captain, and he was released from the military forces on August 23, 1919, during the general demobilization at the end of the war.

Return to Vancouver

After the war, Frank returned to Vancouver.

He and Edna lived in Vancouver until 1925.

To California

In August 1925, Frank and Edna moved to the United States.

By 1930, they were living in Santa Monica, California.

In 1931, Frank and Edna applied to become naturalized United States citizens. They were living at 520 Montana Avenue in Santa Monica.

In 1940, Frank and Edna were still in Santa Monica. Frank was the owner of a wholesale and retail antique business.

Edna died in Santa Monica on September 28, 1954.

Frank died in Santa Monica on February 17, 1956.

It appears that Frank and Edna did not have any children.

Sources
